Award.AbstractNarration:
Although Combinatorics is as old as human's ability to count, its most impressive growth has been seen only in recent decades, mainly due to the rapid development of computer science. Extremal Combinatorics deals with the problems of finding the maximum or minimum value of a function over a class of finite objects. Such problems are often related to other branches of mathematics and other fields of science, including biology, chemistry, computer science, information and coding theory.

The proposed research concentrates on extremal problems for hypergraphs. Since hypergraphs have more complicated structures than graphs, generalizing results from graphs to hypergraphs is usually far from straightforward and frequently gives rise to new phenomena. For example, there are multiple ways (depending on how to define degrees and cycles in hypergraphs) to extend the classical result of Dirac on Hamilton cycles to hypergraphs -- none of them has an easy proof. The Dirac problems, and related matching and packing problems have received considerable attention lately. Modern tools, e.g., the absorbing method and the regularity method, have helped to generate new results, and yet many fundamental problems in the area remain unsolved. The PI plans to tackle many outstanding problems in the area, developing the extremal theory of hypergraphs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hypergraphs have become one of the most rapidly developing areas in modern Combinatorics. Extremal problems on hypergraphs have found applications in many other branches of mathematics and computer science. The Dirac problems refer to a class of problems that relate local conditions to global structures of graphs or hypergraphs. For example, a classical theorem of Dirac determines the minimum degree of a graph that guarantees a Hamilton cycle. The hypergraph extension of this result and related matching and packing problems have received considerable attention in recent years.

 

During the three years funded by this grant, the PI and his collaborators have made major progress on the Dirac problems on hypergraphs. In particular, he published 12 papers on top journals in Combinatorics, such as Journals of Combinatorial Theory A and B, and submitted 5 additional papers. He gave 9 invited talks at national and international conferences in the past three years.

 

The PI has supervised two PhD students, one became a postdoctoral researcher at a research university and the other became a data scientist at AT&T. The PI also mentored a postdoctoral researcher and an undergraduate research project. The PI covered some materials from his research when teaching graduate courses. The students in one of the classes were high school teachers. In addition, he hosted a public lecture that attracted about 100 middle and high school students and parents. He also gave a series of lectures at the math club of a local middle school.
